qas.question: What type of annelids are tube-dwelling?

What gases come from hydrothermal vents?

context: The gut is generally an almost straight tube supported by the mesenteries (vertical partitions within segments), and ends with the anus on the underside of the pygidium. However, in members of the tube-dwelling family <a0_0><b5_0>Siboglinidae<b5_0/><a0_0/> the gut is blocked by <a1_0><b6_0>a swollen lining<b6_0/><a1_0/> that houses symbiotic bacteria, which can make up <a2_0><b7_0>15%<b7_0/><a2_0/> of the worms' total weight. The bacteria convert inorganic matter – such as <a3_0><b8_0>hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide<b8_0/><a3_0/> from hydrothermal vents, or <a4_0><b9_0>methane<b9_0/><a4_0/> from seeps – to organic matter that feeds themselves and their hosts, while the worms extend their palps into the gas flows to absorb the gases needed by the bacteria.
